title: 'Youngest ever' sperm whale calf washes up on UK beach as public urged to stay away
text:
Get the biggest daily news stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

A sperm whale calf has died after washing up on a UK beach in only the second such instance in more than a century.

The public are being urged to stay away from the whale, which marine experts believe could be the youngest ever calf ever stranded on British shores.

The whale has washed up on Hell’s Mouth in Gwynedd, North Wales and the public is being urged to stay away as it may carry diseases which could be transmitted to humans.

NorthWalesLive reports this is the first time a sperm whale has ever washed up on a Welsh beach.

And it only the second time it has happened anywhere in the UK in more than 100 years.

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

A spokesperson of the British Divers Marine Life Rescue (BDMLR) estimated the calf to be between two and three-years-old, which could make it the youngest ever stranded.

The BDMLR spokesperson said: “It is very important to note that cetaceans – whales, dolphins and porpoises – are mammals like us humans, and therefore able to carry serious diseases that can be transmitted between us.

“We would advise members of the public to avoid all contact with the carcass and any bodily fluids to avoid any risk of infection from them.

"There is the possibility that this may have been an animal that was already ill."

The marine mammal is believed to have become stranded yesterday and a team from Cetacean Strandings Investigation Programme (CSIP) and the Zoological society of London are heading to North Wales to examine it and determine the cause of death.

They will be working with a team from Marine Environmental Monitoring.

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

The team of experts told reporters this was an "unusual stranding".

The CSIP are conducting a postmortem later today to determine the cause of death.

The calf hasn't yet developed it teeth, which suggests it was still surviving on milk from its mother.

Usually, a mother sperm whale will to produce milk for the first two years of its calf's life, but they have been known to do so for as long as four years.

Sperm whales usually survive in deep waters and hunt giant squid.

(Image: Shaun O’Riordan / SWNS)

(Image: Scott Simcox)

When a whale finds itself in shallow or inland waters this is more often than not a sign that something has gone wrong, such as a navigational error.

Once in these waters, they generally become trapped and unable to feed which causes them to deteriorate.

A '32ft' humpback whale named 'Hessy' died in the River Thames on October 8 this year.

While a dead humpback whale washed up on the rocks near Dunstanburgh Castle in Northumberland in late September.
description: The whale has washed up on Hell’s Mouth in Gwynedd, North Wales and the public is being urged to stay away
